results.title: The Girls Are Screaming
results.abstract: A shriekathon in “John Proctor Is the Villain” is the latest in a wave of young women letting their pipes loose — and exhorting anyone to join in.

results.title: Man Ray’s Mysteries, in Glorious Bloom at the Met
results.abstract: In his “rayographs,” he raved, he was finally “working directly with light itself.” The showstopper is the most expensive photograph ever sold at auction.

multimedia.caption: Man Ray’s “Le violon d’Ingres,” 1924. The showstopper at the Met, purchased at auction for about $12.4 million, shows Man Ray’s lover, Kiki de Montparnasse (born Alice Prin).
multimedia.copyright: Man Ray 2015 Trust/Artists Rights Society(ARS), NY/ADAGP, Paris 2025; via Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

results.title: Those New Announcements in the Subway? They’re Art
results.abstract: Chloë Bass’s new audio-based public art project will be heard over the P.A. system at 14 M.T.A. stations around New York, urging commuters, “If you hear something, free something.”

multimedia.caption: A new audio-based public art project in the New York City subway that engages commuters, by a conceptual artist, Chloë Bass.

results.title: Mark Volman, Singer of ‘Happy Together’ and Other Hits, Dies at 78
results.abstract: In the 1960s, he and his fellow singer Howard Kaylan embodied the feel-good sound of the Turtles. The two later found new fame as Flo & Eddie.

multimedia.caption: Mark Volman in performance in Atlanta in 1975. He and Howard Kaylan had a string of hits with the Turtles in the 1960s and later toured and recorded as Flo & Eddie.
Mark Volman in performance in Atlanta in 1975. He and Howard Kaylan had a string of hits with the Turtles in the 1960s and later toured and recorded as Flo & Eddie.

results.title: ‘Father Mother Sister Brother’ Takes Top Prize at Venice Film Festival
results.abstract: The film, directed by Jim Jarmusch, details three stories of three families. “The Voice of Hind Rajab,” about a Palestinian girl in a car under fire by the Israeli military, won second place.

multimedia.caption: The director Jim Jarmusch won the Golden Lion for Best Film for “Father Mother Sister Brother” at the 82nd Venice International Film Festival on Saturday.
The director Jim Jarmusch won the Golden Lion for Best Film for “Father Mother Sister Brother” at the 82nd Venice International Film Festival on Saturday.

results.title: Tom Shipley, Whose Ode to Weed Reached the Top 10, Dies at 84
results.abstract: With their “One Toke Over the Line,” he and Michael Brewer saw a musical in-joke turn into a timeless cultural phenomenon.

results.title: Hassan Ouakrim, Who Brought Moroccan Dance to the U.S., Dies
results.abstract: A director and choreographer, he introduced Berber dances and music to New York’s downtown theater scene. He also staged elaborate soirees for the wealthy, one attended by Donald Trump.

multimedia.caption: Hassan Ouakrim in 1982. Through a long association with La MaMa Experimental Theater Club, he fused his region’s traditional dances with an avant-garde approach.
Hassan Ouakrim in 1982. Through a long association with La MaMa Experimental Theater Club, he fused his region’s traditional dances with an avant-garde approach.

results.title: Art Seitz, Whose Camera Caught Tennis Greats On and Off the Court, Dies at 82
results.abstract: Over a 50-year career as a photographer he built friendships with rising stars and captured many of them in their personal environments.

results.title: Barbara Jakobson, Art World Power Broker in New York, Dies at 92
results.abstract: A longtime trustee of the Museum of Modern Art, she was a savvy collector who befriended young artists like Robert Mapplethorpe and made her townhouse a showcase.

multimedia.caption: Barbara Jakobson in 1988. “In the art world, there are artists and curators and dealers and other people with defined roles,” one gallerist said. “But then there are people like Barbara who are essential to how this whole system works.”

Barbara Jakobson in 1988. “In the art world, there are artists and curators and dealers and other people with defined roles,” one gallerist said. “But then there are people like Barbara who are essential to how this whole system works.”

results.title: ‘Riefenstahl’ Review: Hitler’s Favorite Filmmaker Revisited
results.abstract: This cleareyed documentary looks at how Leni Riefenstahl, the director of the Nazi propaganda film “Triumph of the Will,” tirelessly tried to rewrite history.

multimedia.caption: Leni Riefenstahl, who directed Nazi propaganda films, presented herself as an innocent artist — a claim that a new documentary dismantles.
Leni Riefenstahl, who directed Nazi propaganda films, presented herself as an innocent artist — a claim that a new documentary dismantles.
